AND WHAT EXPLAINED THAT WAS --

EACH DIFFERENT.

ALL RIGHT?

-- FUTURE.

IT'S GOT THREE COMPONENTS:

AND THAT PRODUCED DRAMATIC

WHERE WE STILL GOT SIDE BY SIDE

ONE, TWO, THREE OR FOUR PEOPLE,

FACTORY, THE PRODUCTIVITY PER

1020.text:
PER PERSON IS TEN TIMES HIGHER

JUST BY MOVING FROM AN ENTITY OF

AND THEN THERE IS A THIRD

IF YOU ARE WORKING JUST FOR

DON'T PRODUCE ANYTHING.

 THE MANAGEMENT NEEDS TO

1074.text:
MOTIVATE PEOPLE.

EFFECTIVE ORGANIZATIONS, SOME 
ARE IN THE PRIVATE SECTOR, SOME

BUREAUCRACIES.

MODERN SOCIETY.
THERE IS A LOT OF DEBATE AND

AGONIZING OVER SHOULD IT BE

THAT MISSES THE POINT, REALLY.

IN EACH SECTOR, AND THEY 
COMPLEMENT EACH OTHER.

AND AFRICA IS DESPERATELY SHORT 
OF BOTH TYPES.

I'M GOING TO START WITH FIRMS.

SCALE ZERO, SPECIALIZATION ZERO,

PRODUCTIVITY DOOMED TO POVERTY.

AND WHAT ABOUT MODERN FIRMS?
WELL WHAT MODERN FIRMS NEED TO

1177.text:
OPERATE IS NOT VERY COMPLEX.
YOU CAN THINK OF IT AS PLATFORMS

WHICH ENABLE A FIRM TO OPERATE.
AND THOSE PLATFORMS HAVE TWO

ESSENTIAL FEATURES.
ONE IS REALLY OBVIOUS, WHICH IS

ENERGY.
YOU HAVE GOT TO PLUG IN TO A

1194.text:
SOURCE OF ENERGY.
AND THE OTHER IS A LITTLE BIT

1198.text:
MORE SUBTLE, IT'S CONNECTIVITY.

ENERGY, BASICALLY MEANS

WITH FEW EXCEPTIONS, THE

IS PROVIDED BY MONOPOLY PUBLIC

I KNOW THERE IS A NIGERIAN IN

1247.text:
DON'T HAVE TO TELL YOU ABOUT THE
 NATIONAL ELECTRICITY COMPANY.

NEPER STANDS FOR NATIONAL

1262.text:

BECAUSE NIGERIAN ENERGY POLICY

HAS BEEN CAPTURED BY A FEW VERY

AND OVER THE YEARS, THEY HAVE 
REPEATEDLY MANAGED TO BLOCK

1293.text:
ECONOMIC REFORM.

IT'S EASY TO PROVIDE RELIABLE

IT'S A VERY STANDARD TECHNOLOGY 
THAT EVERYBODY ELSE HAS BEEN

AND THE ASCENT FROM LOW

ANYBODY CAN DO SIMPLE, BUT TO DO

AUTOMATICALLY.

SO HOW DO WE MANAGE HIGHER

QUANTA IN GETTING TO HIGHER

THE HUMBLEST LEVEL OF MANAGING 
COMPLEXITY IS THIS:

IT'S TRYING TO STUFF MORE INTO 
THE INDIVIDUAL HUMAN BRAIN.

1426.text:
AND OUR ENTIRE EDUCATION SYSTEM 
AND TRAINING SYSTEM VERY

1431.text:
SENSIBLY IS FOCUSED ON THAT.
LET'S TRY AND GET MORE INTO THE

1440.text:
UNTIL ABOUT 1850, THAT WAS 
PRETTY WELL ALL THAT WE HAD IN

THE WORLD, FOR MANAGING GREATER

BUT SINCE ABOUT 1850, HIGHER

1454.text:
FREE OF THE CONSTRAINT OF WHAT 
CAN YOU GET INTO A SINGLE HEAD.

AND NOWADAYS, COMPLEXITY IS 
MANAGED MAINLY NOT BY PEOPLE WHO

1465.text:
HAVE GOT VAST AMOUNTS IN THEIR 
INDIVIDUAL HEADS, BUT BY

BUILDING TEAMS OF PEOPLE, EACH 
SPECIALIZED, BUT COORDINATED

1478.text:
TOGETHER.
IN THE PRIVATE SECTOR, THAT'S

1479.text:
WHAT A FIRM DOES.
IT MANAGES COMPLEXITY BY

1483.text:
BUILDING A COORDINATED AND 
MOTIVATED TEAM.

NOW, FOR THAT TO HAPPEN, YOU 
NEED A LOT OF SPATIAL

1493.text:
CONNECTIVITY.
WORKERS HAVE TO BE ABLE TO COME

1495.text:
TOGETHER IN THE MORNING AT A 
SINGLE PLACE, THEY HAVE TO BE

ABLE TO GET BACK AT NIGHT, SO 
YOU NEED TO HAVE CONNECTIVITY

1503.text:
BETWEEN WORKERS IN THE FIRM, THE
 FIRM HAS TO REACH ITS

1507.text:
CUSTOMERS, SO YOU NEED 
CONNECTIVITY, FIRM TO CUSTOMERS.

1513.text:
AND CONNECTIVITY IS A SPATIAL 
THING.

IT IS ABOUT THE ABILITY OF 
PEOPLE TO MOVE FROM WHERE THEY

1522.text:
LIVE TO WHERE THEY WORK.
OR FROM THE FACTORY BACK TO

1530.text:
CONSUMERS.
SO THAT'S THE SECOND LEVEL OF

1534.text:
CONNECTIVITY, THE FIRM.
THEN SINCE ABOUT 1970 OR SO, WE

1542.text:
MOVED TO A HIGHER QUANTUM OF 
CONNECTIVITY, WHICH IS BEYOND

2995.text:
TO YOUR OWN ADVANTAGE.
SO THE YOUNG -- THE NEW TAX

2998.text:
COLLECTOR THAT'S JUST COME ON TO
 THE WORKFORCE THIS WEEK, THE

3002.text:
OLD GUYS SAY, GO AND TALK TO 
BENNO THERE, HE REALLY KNOWS A

3007.text:
THING OR TWO.
YOU WILL LEARN FROM HIM.

3011.text:
BUT WHAT THEY LEARN IS NOT HOW 
TO APPLY THE RULES; IT'S HOW TO

3018.text:
ABUSE THE RULES.
SO THAT, I BELIEVE, IS THE TRAP

3023.text:
INTO WHICH A LOT OF PUBLIC 
ORGANIZATIONS IN AFRICA HAVE

3033.text:
PEER-ESTEEM, SELF-ESTEEM, FROM 
BEHAVIOR WHICH IS IN AGGREGATE

3041.text:
SOCIALLY DISASTROUS.
FINALLY, HOW DO WE CHANGE IT?

3045.text:
OR HOW DO THEY CHANGE IT?
AND THERE ARE MANY DIFFERENT

3050.text:
STRATEGIES, BUT I'M GOING TO 
SUGGEST ONE THING THAT IS REALLY

3055.text:
IMPORTANT IS LEADERSHIP.
WE IMAGINE THAT LEADERS ARE

3061.text:
THERE TO TAKE DECISIONS.
THAT ACTUALLY ALSO BEAR AS ROLE

3065.text:
MODELS FOR HA IS GOOD BEHAVIOR 
-- WHAT IS GOOD BEHAVIOR, AND AS

3069.text:
COMMUNICATORS.
WEAVERS OF NARRATIVES, OF HOW

3076.text:
PEOPLE UNDERSTAND THEIR WORLD.
SO LET ME END WITH JUST A FEW

3081.text:
STORIES OF LEADERS THAT MADE A 
DIFFERENCE IN AFRICA.

3085.text:
ONE OF MY HEROES IS PRESIDENT 
ERARE, THE FIRST PRESIDENT OF

3093.text:
TANZANIA.
HE GOT HIS ECONOMICS WRONG.

3095.text:
HE WAS A CREATURE OF HIS TIMES, 
AND THE TIMES, SOCIALIST

3100.text:
ECONOMICS WAS VERY POPULAR, SO 
HE PICKED THAT UP.

3104.text:
THAT DIDN'T DO TANS AN YA VERY 
GOOD.

3106.text:
MORE IMPORTANTLY, HE GOT THE 
IDEA IT WAS VITAL TO PERSUADE

3112.text:
TANZANIANS FIRST AND FOREMOST 
THEIR GROUP IDENTITY WAS THAT

3115.text:
THEY WERE TANZANIAN.
THEY WERE NOT THIS TRIBE OR THAT

3121.text:
HE DID VERY PRACTICAL THINGS TO 
BUILD THAT SHARED IDENTITY.

3133.text:
HE INTRODUCED SYMBOLS OF 
NATIONAL IDENTITY.

3139.text:
HE MADE SURE THAT WHEN HE 
RECRUITED PEOPLE INTO THE CIVIL

3142.text:
SERVICE, THEY WERE NOT ALLOWED 
TO WORK IN THEIR OWN REGION,

3145.text:
THEY WERE MOVED TO ANOTHER 
REGION.

3148.text:
THEY WERE TANZANIAN, NOT JUST 
MEMBERS OF THE LOCAL TRIBE.

3155.text:
AND A FEW YEARS AGO, A VERY 
EMINENT ECONOMIST, TED MIGUEL

3160.text:
DID A STUDY TO SEE WHETHER THAT 
HAD BEEN EFFECTIVE.

3164.text:
AND THE STUDY USED THE FACT THAT
 ACROSS THE BORDER IN KENYA THE

3171.text:
KENYAN LEADER, KENYATTA, HAD 
TAKEN AN EXACTLY OPPOSITE

3175.text:
STRATEGY.
KENYATTA HAD GOT HIS BASIC

3179.text:
ECONOMICS RIGHT, BUT HE HAD GOT 
HIS PROCESS OF SOCIAL IDENTITY

3186.text:
FORMATION DISASTROUSLY WRONG.
HE WAS A KOKUU, HE FAVORED THE

3191.text:
KOKUU.
WHEN HE DIED, HE WAS REPLACED BY

3195.text:
THE VICE PRESIDENT, WHO HAD 
BEEN A KALANJIN.

3198.text:
HE FAVORED THE KALANJIN.
NOW WE ARE BACK TO KOKUU,

3204.text:
FAVORING KOKUU.
FOREYEARS KENYA HAS HAD

3208.text:
REASONABLE ECONOMIC POLICIES, 
BUT A NARRATIVE WHICH HAS

3214.text:
EMPHASIZED TRIBE OVER NATION 
AGAIN AND AGAIN.

3217.text:
SO MIGUEL'S LITTLE STUDY WAS 
DEAD SIMPLE.

3220.text:
IT WENT INTO THE VILLAGES ON 
EITHER SIDE OF THE BORDER.

3228.text:
A STRAIGHT LINE DRAWN IN BERLIN 
IN 1885, WHICH DIVIDES A

3238.text:
PERFECTLY HOMOGENEOUS SOCIETY, 
AND SOME OF THE VILLAGES ON EACH

3242.text:
SIDE OF THE BORDER, A SINGLE 
TRIBE, SOME OF THE VILLAGES ARE

3247.text:
MULTI-TRIBE.
SO MIGUEL THOUGHT, LET'S SEE

3251.text:
WHETHER PEOPLE CAN COOPERATE 
ACROSS THE TRIBAL BOUNDARY TO DO

3255.text:
THE BASIC PUBLIC GOOD THAT A 
VILLAGE NEEDS.

3260.text:
A WELL.
CAN THE VILLAGERS COOPERATE TO

3264.text:
MAINTAIN THE WELL.
AND IN KENYA, PEOPLE CAN

3270.text:
COOPERATE WITHIN A TRIBE, BUT 
NOT ACROSS TRIBES.

3274.text:
SO A SINGLE TRIBE VILLAGES HAD A
 FUNCTIONING WELL, THE

3280.text:
MULTI-TRIBE VILLAGES DIDN'T.
THEN HE WENT AND LOOKED ACROSS

3285.text:
THE BORDER IN TANS AN -- 
TANZANIA.

3288.text:
AND IT MADE NO DIFFERENCE 
WHETHER THE VILLAGE WAS

3293.text:
MULTI-TRIBAL OR SINGLE TRIBE.
THEY WERE ABLE TO COOPERATE TO

3296.text:
MAINTAIN THE WELL.
AND SO 40 YEARS OF VERY

3302.text:
DIFFERENT NARRATIVES HAD BUILT 
VERY DIFFERENT IDENTITIES, AND

3306.text:
THAT HAD VERY PRACTICAL 
CONSEQUENCES FOR THE ABILITY TO

3312.text:
COOPERATE.
SO THAT WAS ERARI GETTING

3320.text:
CHANGING PEOPLE'S IDENTITY.
LET'S THINK ABOUT CHANGING

3324.text:
PEOPLE'S NORMS.
AND I'VE GOT TWO EXPERIENCES

3328.text:
THERE.
I'M COMING TO A CLOSE.

3331.text:
ONE OF MY CURRENT HEROES IS THE 
CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF CAMPALI, THE

3338.text:
BIGGEST CITY IN UGANDA.
AND SHE'S CALLED JENNIFER

3344.text:
MUSIZI, A FANTASTIC WOMAN.
SHE'S BUILT A TEAM OF 50 PEOPLE,

3348.text:
WHO ARE ALL AS MOTIVATED AS 
PASSIONATE, ABOUT IMPROVING

3356.text:
KAMPALA AS SHE IS.
AND I WAS MYSTIFIED TO THINK,

3360.text:
JENNIFER, HOW HAVE YOU DONE IT?
WHAT DID YOU DO TO BUILD A

3366.text:
MOTIVATED TEAM.
AND SHE SAID, WELL, FIRST OF

3368.text:
ALL, IT WAS PRETTY SIMPLE.
I HAVE BEEN APPOINTED BY THE

3371.text:
PRESIDENT, SO I HAD POWER.
SO MY FIRST JOB, MY FIRST ACT

3377.text:
WAS TO FIRE EVERYBODY.
THAT MEANT THE NEXT DAY I DIDN'T

3380.text:
HAVE ANYBODY, SO I HAD TO 
REHIRE SOME OF THE PEOPLE.

3384.text:
BUT I MADE SURE THAT NOBODY WENT
 BACK TO THEIR OLD JOB.

3388.text:
IN FACT, I CHANGED ALL THE JOB 
DESCRIPTIONS.

3392.text:
SO IT WAS AS CLEAR AS POSSIBLE 
THAT TOMORROW WAS GOING TO BE

3398.text:
DIFFERENT.
AND THEN WHAT SHE DIDN'T TELL

3399.text:
ME, BUT I SAW, WAS SHE LED BY 
EXAMPLE.

3404.text:
SHE IS THERE EARLY IN THE 
MORNING, SHE IS THERE LATE AT

3413.text:
TANZANIA JUST GOT A NEW 
PRESIDENT.

3419.text:
AND WHEN A NEW PRESIDENT TAKES 
POWER IN AFRICA, THE

3423.text:
INAUGURATION CEREMONY IS USUALLY
 A VERY FLAMBOYANT, NOT TO SAY

3430.text:
EXPENSIVE EVENT.
A CELEBRATION OF A PRESIDENT

3437.text:
AND PRESIDENT MUGAFULI DECIDED 
THIS WASN'T APPROPRIATE.

3442.text:
TANZANIA IS A VERY POOR COUNTRY,
 FACING A STRUGGLE.

3446.text:
SO HE CANCELLED ALL THE 
INAUGURATION CEREMONY, AND

3450.text:
INSTEAD HE SPENT HIS FIRST DAY 
WITH A BRUSH, SWEEPING THE

3456.text:
STREETS OF DAR ES SALAAM.
OKAY?

3459.text:
I WASN'T THERE ON THAT DAY, I 
WAS THERE SHORTLY AFTER.

3462.text:
I LEARNED ABOUT IT FROM THE TAXI
 DRIVERS, BECAUSE THEY WERE ALL

3468.text:
DEEPLY IMPRESSED.
THIS WAS A SIGNAL TO THEM THAT

3473.text:
MUGAFULI WAS GOING TO LIVE 
DIFFERENTLY, WAS GOING TO ACT

3478.text:
WE'LL SEE WHETHER HE CONTINUES 
TO WALK THE TALK.

3481.text:
BUT IT WAS A GOOD START.
SO YOU CAN CHANGE NORMS BY

3490.text:
PERSONAL EXAMPLE.
IF YOU LIVE LIKE A LORD, YOU

3495.text:
CANNOT THEN PREACH THAT THE 
PEOPLE SHOULD BE HONEST AND WORK

3500.text:
HARD.
MY FINAL EXAMPLE, SO WE CHANGED

3504.text:
IDENTITIES, WE CHANGED NORMS.
MY FINAL EXAMPLE IS CHANGING

3510.text:
NARRATIVES.
AND THIS IS GOING TO BE THE

3512.text:
STORY OF MY GREATEST HERO IN 
AFRICA.

3516.text:
HE'S DEAD NOW.
SIR ETSY KANA.

3523.text:
I AM PART TO BE A PART OF 
BOTSWANA SOCIETY, THAT'S WHY I'M

3526.text:
WEARING THIS TIE TODAY.
THIS TIE IS THE TIE OF THE

3528.text:
CENTRAL BANK OF BOTSWANA.
BOTSWANA'S FEDERAL RESERVE, AND

3534.text:
I'M ON THE BOARD.
I AM VERY PROUD OF THAT.

3540.text:
SO WHAT DID SIRETSY KAMA DO?
WHEN HE CAME INTO POWER,

3550.text:
BOTSWANA WAS POOR, LANDLOCKED, 
ARID, IMPOVERISHED.

3554.text:
IT IS NOW ABOUT THE RICHEST 
COUNTRY IN AFRICA.

3556.text:
HOW DID HE DO IT?
WELL, THE ECONOMIC REASON IS

3564.text:
THAT BOTSWANA FOUND DIAMONDS.
BUT SO DID SIERRA LEONE, AND

3569.text:
SIERRA LEONE DROPPED TO THE 
BOTTOM OF THE WORLD HUMAN

3572.text:
DEVELOPMENT INDEX AS A RESULT OF
 DIAMONDS.

3573.text:
SO NATURAL RESOURCES ARE NOT THE
 ROYLE ROAD TO

3580.text:
PROSPERITY, FAR FROM IT.
BUT KAMA DID TWO THINGS VERY

3585.text:
SENSIBLE.
ONE IS, HE WENT ROUND ALL THE

3588.text:
CLAN LEADERS, SAYING WE'RE GOING
 TO LOOK FOR DIAMONDS.

3591.text:
THE NEIGHBORING COUNTRIES HAVE 
THEM, WE DON'T KNOW WHETHER WE

3594.text:
GOT THEM, BUT WE PROBABLY GOT 
THEM.

3596.text:
WE GOT TO DECIDE WHO OWNS THEM.
THEY COULD BELONG TO WHOEVER,

3603.text:
WHICHEVER CLAN FINDS THEM, ARE 
OR THEY COULD BELONG TO ALL OF

3607.text:
US.  
WHICH AS CLAN LEADERS WOULD YOU

3608.text:
PREFER?
CLAN LEADERS THOUGHT ABOUT IT.

3610.text:
YOU DON'T HAVE TO THINK ABOUT IT
 VERY HARD TO REALIZE THE BEST

3615.text:
THING IS, WE BETTER ALL SHARE 
IT.

3617.text:
ALL RIGHT?
THE NIGHTMARE IS THE CLAN NEXT

3620.text:
DOOR FINDS THEM AND YOU DON'T.
IT'S SAFER JUST TO SHARE.

3625.text:
RIGHT?
NOW, THAT MADE KAMA A VERY

3631.text:
FAR-SIGHTED MAN.
WHY HE WAS A GREAT MAN IS THAT

3633.text:
THE MINING COMPANIES HAD GIVEN 
HIM A LITTLE BIT OF ADVANCED

3637.text:
GEOLOGY AND SAID THERE'S 
DEFINITELY DIAMONDS UNDER YOUR

3640.text:
CLAN.
HE PUT THE NATIONAL INTERESTS

3643.text:
AHEAD OF HIS OWN CLAN.
THAT'S GREATNESS.

3647.text:
AND IF BRITAIN HAD DONE THAT 
WHEN WE STARTED PROSPECTING FOR

3653.text:
OIL, WE WOULDN'T HAVE NOW BE IN 
THE SITUATION WHERE A COUNTRY

3658.text:
THAT'S 309 YEARS OLD MAY WELL 
SPLIT APART.

3662.text:
WITH SCOTLAND, SAYING IT'S 
SCOTLAND'S OIL.

3670.text:
KAMA's OTHER GREAT CHANGE, ONCE 
WE GOT -- ONCE BOTSWANA HAD GOT

3674.text:
THE DIAMONDS, WAS TO INTRODUCE A
 VERY SIMPLE NARRATIVE, WHICH

3681.text:
EVERY BOTSWANAN KNEW AND STILL 
KNOWS.

3684.text:
THAT IS, WE'RE POOR SHALL AND 
THEREFORE WE HAVE TO CARRY A

3693.text:
I WAS JUST IN TANZANIA RECENTLY 
WHERE THEY DISCOVERED GAS, AND I

3700.text:
TALKED TO THE COMMISSIONER, IT 
WAS OFFSHORE GAS, BUT SURE

3705.text:
ENOUGH, THE REGION WHERE IT WAS 
DISCOVERED WITHIN MONTHS, PEOPLE

3711.text:
WERE SAYING, IT'S MATWARA's 
GAS, NOT TANZANIAN, AND THEY

3716.text:
WERE SAYING, WE'RE RICH!  
WE DON'T HAVE TO WORK ANYMORE!

3719.text:
IF YOU THINK ABOUT IT, THAT 
PHRASE, WE'RE RICH, WE DON'T

3723.text:
HAVE TO WORK ANYMORE, IS ALMOST 
VERBATIM THE OPPOSITE OF "WE'RE

3727.text:
POOR, WE HAVE TO CARE A HEAVY 
LOAD."

3730.text:
AND WHAT KAMA DID WITH THAT 
PHRASE, HE IMMUNIZED A

3737.text:
POPULATION AGAINST THE 
TEMPTATION OF POP U LITTLE --

3743.text:
POPULISM.
WE FOUND DIAMONDS, LET'S THROW A

3746.text:
WE FOUND DIAMONDS, SO WE ARE 
GOING TO USE THEM PRUDENTLY,

3749.text:
GRADUALLY TO LIFT OURSELVES OUT 
OF POVERTY.

3751.text:
WHICH IS WHAT BOTSWANA DID.
SO I APOLOGIZE, I'VE TAKEN YOU

3760.text:
ON A LONG TOUR, AND THROUGH THE,
 AS IT WERE, THE FOUNDATIONS OF

3767.text:
ECONOMICS, THE MIRACLE OF 
PRODUCTIVITY, EFFECTIVE

3776.text:
THEY ARE WHAT AFRICA NEEDS, THEY
 ARE WHAT AFRICA HAS GOT TO

3779.text:
BUILD IN THE COMING DECADE.
THANK YOU VERY MUCH.
